review.title: Complexity of Inference in Graphical Models
review.abstract: It is well-known that inference in graphical models is hard in the worst case, but tractable for models with bounded treewidth. We ask whether treewidth is the only structural criterion of the underlying graph that enables tractable inference. In other words, is there some class of structures with unbounded treewidth in which inference is tractable? Subject to a combinatorial hypothesis due to Robertson et al. (1994), we show that low treewidth is indeed the only structural restriction that can ensure tractability. Thus, even for the "best case" graph structure, there is no inference algorithm with complexity polynomial in the treewidth.

sections.text: It is well known that inferences in graphical models are difficult at worst, but understandable for models with limited tree width. We ask whether tree width is the only structural criterion of the underlying graph that allows comprehensible inferences. In other words, is there any class of structures with unlimited tree width in which inferences are comprehensible? Subject to a combinatorial hypothesis based on Robertson et al. (1994), we show that low tree width is in fact the only structural constraint that can ensure traceability.

sections.heading: 2.2 UNIFORM VS. NON-UNIFORM ALGORITHMS
sections.text: The classical conception of algorithms refers to "uniform algorithms," in which one has a single algorithm that works for all input lengths. An "unequal algorithm," on the other hand, refers to a family of algorithms, one for each input length. A different way of thinking about such unequal algorithms is that the algorithm is allowed to receive any oracle advice that only depends on the input length (but not on the actual input length). In the theory of calculation literature, such "unequal algorithms" are usually referred to as "fixed-input circuits," in which a different circuit is used for each input length. Class P is the class of problems with polynomial simultaneous algorithms, while P / Poly is their unequal counterpart, i.e. the class of problems that have polynomically identical algorithms (circuits).

sections.heading: 6 CONCLUSION
sections.text: With increasing interest in understanding different inference methods and providing conditions under which they are correct and comprehensible, it is important to understand whether there could actually be a structural property that can guarantee a comprehensible conclusion in addition to tree width. In this paper, we have examined, presented and discussed the relevant literature from the CSP community, as well as relevant concepts of graph theory, and can conclude that such an alternative property is not likely - finding a property that ensures the traceability of the conclusion without limiting tree width would mean providing a counter-example to Robertson's and Seymour Grid-Minor hypothesis. Nevertheless, it would be of great interest to prove the results in this paper without resorting to the Grid-Minor hypothesis. It would also be useful to obtain hardness results that apply to even the "simplest" high-tree width graph structures.
